{{marriage|Karon Blackwell|1984}} | website = {{Official website|http://www.martyallenhellodere.com/}} }} '''Morton David Alpern''' (March 23, 1922 – February 12, 2018), better known as '''Marty Allen''', was an American comedian, actor, and philanthropist. He worked as a comedy headliner in [[nightclub]]s, as a dramatic actor in television roles, and was once called "The Darling of Daytime TV". He also appeared in films, notably the 1966 spy comedy ''[[The Last of the Secret Agents?]]'' During his comedy career, Allen also toured military hospitals, performed for veterans, and for active military personnel. Allen was also a philanthropist. He contributed to the [[American Cancer Society]], The Heart Fund, the [[March of Dimes]], [[Fight for Sight (U.S.)|Fight for Sight]], and served on the board of the [[Epilepsy Foundation]]. ==Early life== Allen was born in [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], to Jewish parents; Louis Alpern (1898–1977; from Romania/Russia), a restaurant and bar owner{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/local/obituaries/marty-allen-fuzzy-haired-member-of-popular-1960s-comedy-duo-allen-and-rossi-dies-at-95/2018/02/13/7f7cb81a-10d7-11e8-9570-29c9830535e5_story.html|title=Marty Allen, fuzzy-haired member of popular 1960s comedy duo Allen & Rossi, dies at 95|publisher=The Washington Post|date=13 February 2018|author=Schudel, Matt}} and his wife, the former Elsie Moss (1901–1979).{{cn|date=March 2018}} He graduated from [[Taylor Allderdice High School]] in 1940. He was inducted into their alumni Hall Of Fame in 2009.{{cite news|last=Hecht|first=Steve|title=Comedian Marty Allen part of Allderdice's first hall class|url=http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/local/neighborhoods-east/comedian-marty-allen-part-of-allderdices-first-hall-class-355087/|access-date=July 18, 2012|newspaper=Pittsburgh Post-Gazette|date=August 27, 2009|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130830192620/http://www.post-gazette.com/stories/local/neighborhoods-east/comedian-marty-allen-part-of-allderdices-first-hall-class-355087/|archivedate=August 30, 2013|df=mdy-all}} Allen joined the [[United States Army Air Corps|U.S. Army Air Corps]] during World War II. He was stationed in [[Italy]] where he attained the rank of sergeant. He earned a [[Soldier's Medal]] for stopping a fire in a plane that was being refueled. He saved the lives of the men boarding the burning plane by driving the fuel truck away, returning on foot to the plane, and then putting out the fire by rolling over the flames with his body in uniform. His heroism earned him a full-dress parade.{{cite web |url=http://www.jewishlasvegas.com/local_includes/downloads/33565.pdf |title="Both Sides of Marty Allen" ''The Jewish Reporter'', May 22, 2009 |access-date=June 6, 2009 |date=May 2009 |format=PDF |work=www.JewishLasVegas.com |page=30 |quote= |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110713104830/http://www.jewishlasvegas.com/local_includes/downloads/33565.pdf |archivedate=July 13, 2011 |df= }} He was married to the former Lorraine "Frenchy" Trydelle, who was the reservation and office manager of the [[Concord Resort Hotel]] in the Catskills,{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e8zSadEAzOMC&pg=PA160&lpg=PA160&dq=lorraine+frenchy+trydelle&source=bl&ots=fg2qBUhg1S&sig=F8qWewp3Gz2lfcZTFl8elzhQ5Pc&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiRjM6jzKTZAhVL92MKHc4QC18Q6AEwCHoECAcQAQ#v=onepage&q=lorraine+frenchy+trydelle&f=false|title=It Happened in the Catskills|publisher=SUNY Press|via=Google Books}} from 1960 until her death in 1976.{{cite web|url=https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/149349142/|title=The Pittsburgh Press from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania on January 20, 1963 · Page 112|publisher=}} ==Career== During the early to the mid-1950s, Allen and his first comedy partner, Mitch DeWood, worked as an [[opening act]] for stars including [[Sarah Vaughan]], [[Eydie Gormé]], and [[Nat King Cole]]. Allen and DeWood also worked many clubs, including the [[Copacabana (nightclub)|Copacabana]] until they broke up in 1958 and went their separate ways.{{cite web|url=http://www.msn.com/en-us/tv/news/marty-allen-comedian-and-game-show-regular-dies-at-95/ar-BBJ3CSe?li=BBmkt5R&ocid=ientp|title=Marty Allen, Comedian and Game Show Regular, Dies at 95|publisher=msn.com|access-date=February 13, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213222230/http://www.msn.com/en-us/tv/news/marty-allen-comedian-and-game-show-regular-dies-at-95/ar-BBJ3CSe?li=BBmkt5R&ocid=ientp|archivedate=February 13, 2018|df=mdy-all}} He then became part of the comedy team of [[Allen & Rossi]] with [[Steve Rossi]], which resulted in a string of hit comedy albums, 44 appearances on ''[[The Ed Sullivan Show]]'' (including the famous appearance by [[The Beatles]] on 16 February 1964, during which Allen won over the Beatles fans in the audience by announcing "I'm Ringo's mother!"),{{cite book|last=Nachman|first=Gerald|title=Right Here On Our Stage Tonight: Ed Sullivan's America|date=2010|publisher=University of California Press|location=Berkeley|isbn=978-0520268012|page=226|chapter=Inside the Star-Making Machine}} and the film ''[[The Last of the Secret Agents?]]'' (1966).{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/comedian-marty-allen-dies-in-las-vegas-at-95/2018/02/12/61e3a4e4-1073-11e8-a68c-e9374188170e_story.html|title=Comedian Marty Allen Dies in Las Vegas at 95|publisher=The Washington Post|date=February 13, 2018|accessdate=February 13, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213222230/https://www.washingtonpost.com/entertainment/tv/comedian-marty-allen-dies-in-las-vegas-at-95/2018/02/12/61e3a4e4-1073-11e8-a68c-e9374188170e_story.html|archivedate=February 13, 2018|df=mdy-all}} They worked together from 1957 to 1968, parted ways amicably, and reunited for shows from the 1970s through the 1990s. In 1961 and 1962, Allen appeared on Broadway in ''[[Let It Ride (musical)|Let It Ride!]]'' at the [[Eugene O'Neill Theatre]] and then went on to perform in the pre-Broadway tour and Broadway performances of ''[[I Had a Ball]]'' in 1964. He eventually began performing dramatic roles. His debut as a serious actor came on ''[[The Big Valley]]'' television series as the hapless Waldo Diefendorfer.{{cite web|url=http://www.allmovie.com/artist/marty-allen-1041|title=''Allmovie Database''|publisher=allmovie.com|access-date=December 1, 2010|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090917005057/http://www.allmovie.com/artist/marty-allen-1041|archivedate=September 17, 2009|df=mdy-all}} Throughout the 1970s and into the 1980s, he made hundreds of television appearances, becoming a regular on ''[[The Hollywood Squares]]''. He appeared on ''[[Circus of the Stars]]'', in a cameo on ''[[The Super Mario Bros. Super Show!]]'', on game shows such as ''[[Password (game show)|Password]]'', and in ten [[Television film|made-for-television movies]]. He also appeared in theatrical films such as ''[[The Great Waltz (1972 film)|The Great Waltz]]'' (1972), ''[[The Harrad Experiment|Harrad Summer]]'' (1974) and ''A Whale of a Tale'' (1976). From the 1980s he and his wife, singer-songwriter Karon Kate Blackwell, teamed up to perform their musical comedy act to audiences around the country. In 2007, the duo began performing at the [[Gold Coast Hotel and Casino]] in [[Las Vegas Valley|Las Vegas]] and went on to perform at the [[South Point Hotel, Casino & Spa|Southpoint Casino]], at [[Palace Station]], and on cruise ships.[http://classicshowbiz.blogspot.com/2011/05/interview-with-marty-allen-part-one.html An Interview with Marty Allen] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723160844/http://classicshowbiz.blogspot.com/2011/05/interview-with-marty-allen-part-one.html |date=July 23, 2011 }}, classicshowbiz.blogspot.com (May 2011). In 2015, the couple continued to perform in venues around the country to overflow crowds, at the [[Rampart Casino]]{{cite web|url=http://www.vegas24seven.com/?p=46929 |title=Legendary Comedian Marty Allen Performs at Rampart Casino, April 17 – |website=Vegas24seven.com |date= |access-date=March 24, 2017}} and the [[Downtown Grand]] in Las Vegas.{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/travel/lasvegas/lasvegasnow/la-tr-lvn-las-vegas-shows-marty-allen-20150304-story.html |title=Comedian Marty Allen celebrates his 93rd birthday with two Vegas shows |first=Susan |last=Stapleton |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=March 5, 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160414020834/http://www.latimes.com/travel/lasvegas/lasvegasnow/la-tr-lvn-las-vegas-shows-marty-allen-20150304-story.html |archivedate=April 14, 2016 |df=mdy-all }} In 2016, they performed at the Metropolitan Room in New York City.[http://www.thespectrum.com/story/entertainment/2016/03/17/marty-allens-still-making-em-laugh/81818590/ Interview with Marty Allen], thespectrum.com, March 2016. ==Charitable work== In 1968, he made a "Hello Dere" tour of military hospitals in the United States (a tour named after a [[catchphrase]] he popularized).{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/13/obituaries/marty-allen-wild-eyed-comedy-star-is-dead-at-95.html|title=Marty Allen, Wild-Eyed Comedian, Dies at 95|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 13, 2018|accessdate=February 13, 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213222230/https://www.nytimes.com/2018/02/13/obituaries/marty-allen-wild-eyed-comedy-star-is-dead-at-95.html|archivedate=February 13, 2018|df=mdy-all}} He repeated the tour annually until 1972. During the tours, he talked with and entertained wounded soldiers who had just returned from [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]].{{cite web|url=http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2018/02/13/comedian-marty-allen-dead-at-95.html|title=Comedian Marty Allen Dies at 95|publisher=Fox|date=February 2018|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213141852/http://www.foxnews.com/entertainment/2018/02/13/comedian-marty-allen-dead-at-95.html|archivedate=February 13, 2018|df=mdy-all}} He was also involved in a number of charitable causes including the [[American Cancer Society]], The Heart Fund, [[March of Dimes]], [[Fight for Sight (U.S.)|Fight for Sight]], [[cerebral palsy|Cerebral Palsy]], and was on the board of the [[Epilepsy Foundation]]. ==Death== Allen died at the age of 95 on February 12, 2018, of complications from pneumonia at his home in Las Vegas.{{Cite news|url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/marty-allen-dead-zany-comedian-was-95-925520|title=Marty Allen, Zany Comedian With a Crazy Hairdo, Dies at 95|work=The Hollywood Reporter|access-date=2018-02-16|language=en}} His wife and performing partner Karon Kate Blackwell was by his side.{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-marty-allen-20180212-story.html |title=Comedian Marty Allen dies in Las Vegas at 95 |agency=[[Associated Press]] |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |date=February 12, 2018 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213124603/http://www.latimes.com/local/obituaries/la-me-marty-allen-20180212-story.html |archivedate=February 13, 2018 |df=mdy-all }} His interment was at [[Eden Memorial Park Cemetery]] in [[Mission Hills, California]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official
